dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey B, another really tough week, you know, with all the news about, um, violent events unfolding. It really makes you think about how the media covers these things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey B, another really tough week, you know, with all the news about, um, violent events unfolding. It really makes you think about how the media covers these things.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, A, absolutely. And especially in this day and age, like, where everything just spreads so fast online, how journalists respond is, uh, just so crucial.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, A, absolutely. And especially in this day and age, like, where everything just spreads so fast online, how journalists respond is, uh, just so crucial.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And that brings us to Dr. James Donovan, from Harvard Kennedy School's TaSC Project. He's really, I mean, he's a leader in examining online extremism and, uh, media manipulation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And that brings us to Doctor James Donovan, from Harvard Kennedy School's T A S C Project. He's really, I mean, he's a leader in examining online extremism and, uh, media manipulation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Joan Donovan is Director of the Technology and Social Change (TaSC) Research Project at the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School. Dr. Donovan leads the field in examining internet and technology studies, online extremism, media manipulation, and disinformation campaigns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he's been weighing in on things like the Aurora, Colorado shooting, which, you know, tragically highlighted this common thread among perpetrators: these extremist manifestos.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he's been weighing in on things like the Aurora, Colorado shooting, which, you know, tragically highlighted this common thread among perpetrators: these extremist manifestos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Joan Donovan, Research Director, responds to El Paso shooting... The shooting in an El Paso, Texas Walmart this weekend is another tragedy in a string of extremist violence happening across not only the United States, but around the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're, like, published online right before an attack, and then they just get amplified everywhere – social media, mainstream news. It’s a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're, like, published online right before an attack, and then they just get amplified everywhere - social media, mainstream news. It's a huge problem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These manifestos are published online before the beginning of the attack, and amplified through social media and mainstream news.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Dr. Donovan's main advice for journalists here is, um, what he calls "strategic silence" when it comes to these manifestos.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Doctor Donovan's main advice for journalists here is, um, what he calls strategic silence when it comes to these manifestos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Donovan advocates that the media practice strategic silence when reporting on the manifestos.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which makes so much sense, right? Like, their goal is wide distribution of these hateful ideas. So, republishing them just gives them undue influence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes so much sense, right? Like, their goal is wide distribution of these hateful ideas. So, republishing them just gives them undue influence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Wide distribution of extremist ideas is one goal of these violent attacks, so republishing the attackers manifesto provides them undue influence over important public debates and can potentially inspire others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Instead, he says, you know, humanize the victims. Show their pictures, share their biographies, tell compelling stories from *their* perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Instead, he says, you know, humanize the victims. Show their pictures, share their biographies, tell compelling stories from their perspective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Donovan recommends that journalists humanize those who were targeted with pictures and biographies, highlight civil society organizations that work with targeted populations, and tell compelling stories from the perspective of victims.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And also highlight civil society organizations that are working with targeted populations, which is, uh, another great angle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And also highlight civil society organizations that are working with targeted populations, which is, uh, another great angle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Donovan recommends that journalists humanize those who were targeted with pictures and biographies, highlight civil society organizations that work with targeted populations, and tell compelling stories from the perspective of victims.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just about extremist manifestos for TaSC, either. They look at the broader media manipulation landscape, the whole disinformation ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just about extremist manifestos for T A S C, either. They look at the broader media manipulation landscape, the whole disinformation ecosystem.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Technology and Social Change (TaSC) Research Project, led by Dr. Donovan, looks not just at extremist events, but also the broader media manipulation landscape and disinformation ecosystem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's fascinating. So, they're trying to understand how media manipulation can, like, control public conversation, derail democracy...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's fascinating. So, they're trying to understand how media manipulation can, like, control public conversation, derail democracy...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The TaSC project aims to understand how media manipulation is a means to control public conversation, derail democracy, and disrupt society.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. And they’re not just researching, they’re developing tools, running workshops for journalists, policymakers, even advising congressional offices on content moderation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. And they're not just researching, they're developing tools, running workshops for journalists, policymakers, even advising congressional offices on content moderation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The TaSC project conducts research, develops tools, and facilitates workshops for journalists, policy makers, technologists, and civil society organizations on how to detect, document, and debunk media manipulation campaigns. The TaSC project is also advising congressional offices on content moderation policies and nation-wide civil society organizations on how to address media manipulation campaigns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so really practical, actionable stuff. I mean, the Shorenstein Center at Harvard is clearly putting a lot of weight behind this work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, so really practical, actionable stuff. I mean, the Shorenstein Center at Harvard is clearly putting a lot of weight behind this work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. Nancy Gibbs, the Director, talks about strengthening the "ecosystem of information." And Setti Warren emphasizes how valuable this research-based policy advice is.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. Nancy Gibbs, the Director, talks about strengthening the ecosystem of information. And Setti Warren emphasizes how valuable this research-based policy advice is.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nancy Gibbs, Director: The Shorenstein Centers mission is to strengthen the ecosystem of information that advances a free society. ... Setti Warren, Executive Director: From my time as a public policy maker I know how valuable reliable, research-based and evidence-based policy advice is at all levels of government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's all about, um, diagnosing what's gone wrong with the internet, and then building a better one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's all about, um, diagnosing what's gone wrong with the internet, and then building a better one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Through the Technology and Social Change Research Project, Joan and her team are doing vital work to diagnose what has gone wrong, and propose concrete solutions to build a better internet, and the promise of a better world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Real evidence-based solutions for, uh, online hate speech and extremism. It's crucial work right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Real evidence-based solutions for, uh, online hate speech and extremism. It's crucial work right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: TaSC is providing the people who are crafting these policies with real evidence-based and research-based policy solutions.
